div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28 | R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18 | R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9,
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS, 31-12-905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents. 26-12-905

div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country!

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

div.head: The National Hotel, Cairo
Opens 1st November, 1905.
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fasnionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle a manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts.
English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit every one.
For further particulars apply to:
General Manager, Cairo.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: Savoy Hotel, Luxor (Upper Egypt).
div.p: New First Class Hotel With Every Modern Comfort.

Splendid Situation on the Bank of the Nile, on the road to Karnak and within easy reach of Thebes Magnificent Vistas, Beautiful Surroundings, Garden, Spacious Terrace overlooking the River, Billar l. Room, Smoking-Room, Reading-Room, Electric Light throughout.
Restaurant open to Non-Residents.- Moderate Charges
Omnibus and Porter meet all Train and Steamers.
Opening In November.
G. & Runckewitz, Preprietors.
Telegr. Add. Savoy, Luxor.
Also Prop. of the Beau-Rivags Hotel, Hamleh-Alexandria.

div.head: Monday, October 9, 1905.
Austria And Hungary.
div.p: That public opinion in Hungary has been bitterly offended by the attitude of the Em- peror Francis Joseph is perhaps natural enough. Coldness to the five representatives of the Hungarian Parliamentary coalition was resented as an insult to the nation, and the Magyar people is to-day in a dangerous mood. Althought a large proportion of its territories are inhab- ited by hostile or indifferent Slavs and Roumanians, and though the application of the proposed new army law by which com- mands must be issued in Magyar to all the Hungarian contingents in the army of the dual monarchy, might lead to the unpleasant discovery that more than a third of the offi- cers of the Hungarian Crown were German by origin and language, still the Magyar people seems ready to press Austria for the fulfilment of its demands. The correspon- dent of the "Standard" at Vienna gives the following interesting summary of the present situation, which appears to explain the mo- tive of the sudden and disconcerting action of the Emperor-King.

"There is no blinking the fact that Hungary for months past has been in a state of actual revolt against the Crown. The Parliament has refused to vote the contingents of recruits, or the Army Budget, or to ratify commericial treaties, whilst the the municipalities, in obedience to the Coalition, have refused to collect taxes or to pay rates. Whilst nominally living under the Government of the Fejervary Cabinet, samed and appointed by the King, the Hungarians have systematically refused to obey its orders, and have been pratically governed in republican fashion by themselves and their own represantitives. A peaceful revolution, it is true, based on the constitu- tional grounds that the Government did not command a majority, and therefore was no Government ; but, since the majority refused to take over the reins except on conditions which destroyed the little prerogative the King possessed, it amounted to a very real revolution against the Crown. The King bore with this for a long time, and might have borne it longer, were it not that, besides being King of Hungary, he was, and is, Emperor of Austria, and the passive revolution in Hungary began to react seriously, and threatened to react very much more seriously, if it continued, in Austria. It became clearer day by day that the longer the Coalition was left to dominate in Hungary the more difficult it would become to bring the country back into line with Austria, and indeed the wider grew the gap which menaced to seperate the two countries altogether. Six months ago the language used to-day would have been deemed impossible, and the rupture is now discussed as an undesirable possi- bility, but a possibility all the same. It is believed, however, that Hungary is not yet prepared financially to cut herself off from Austria, however loudly politicians may talk, and it is probably in the strength of this belief that the Emperor issued his ultima- tum. That she is not prepared is demonstrable, but a race like the Hungarian does not always count the cost before acting, and herein lies the danger. On the other hand, though the Hungarians govern Hungary, at least one- third of the population is alien- German, Polish, Slovak, Ruthenian, Serb, and Croatian. If ever the question of seperation between Hungary and Austria arose, is is not at all clear what position these nationalities might take up. They might insist on a maintenance of the dualism, or they might decide to join Austria or their kindred States. These nation- alities, habing at present practically no vote and no voice, can never make themselves heard, and from Hungary comes only the Magyar trumpet. If, however, universal suffrace were introduced a great change would come over the scene-nor is it likely that the monar- chy could be dissolved without their having a word in the matter. And herein lies the grand mistake of the Hungarian Independence Party, in that they have moved too soon. Had they waited another fifteen or twenty years they might have developed their manu- factures and industries, and by doubling their present system have Magyarised another fourth of the population. They could then have come forth boldly to speak to the enemy at the gate. As it is, they must be conscious of internal weakness, and they have the nightmare of the universal suffrage, which will give votes to all the feared and hated "nationalities," always dogging their steps. They have been brought up with a sudden check of the lasso, and it will be wise if they measure their strengthg well ere they stiffen their necks against the strain. They are orally sure of Hungary for the Hunga- rians if they bide their time, but they have to learn the value of the precept Festina lente."

div.head: SOCIETE EGYPTIENNE D’irrigation
div.p: Il resulte du rapport publie par les soins de la Societe que le compte de la Societe des Sucreries preseute dans la comptabilite da la Socidte Egyptienne un solde Crediteur d L.E. 1.132.969 m/m. Dans ces conditions’, l deconfiture des Sucreries ne peut pas affecte la Societe Egyptienne.

“ Cependant — ajoute l’expert — la Socie genderala des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte ayant garanti aux souscripteurs de la derniere emission des 1,000 Actions de votre societe, un interet minimum de 6 1/2 par an, pendant 10 ans a compter du ler aout 1902, ainsi que pour le principal et les interests des obligations emises par votre societe pour une somme de L.E. 40,000, on doit se demander quelle valeur peut avoir aujourd’hui cette ga- rautie, en presence de la situation actualle de la dite Societe generale.

", Il est a noter qn’en exdecution de ses enga- gements du 19 septembre 1902, fa Societe ger- nerale a parfait un et demi pour cent sur les millie actions de la derniere emission pendant les exercices 1902-1903 et 1904-1905, et fourni la totalite du 6 1/2 pour cent pour l’exercise 1903-1901, exercise pour lequel il n'a pas ete distribue dividende.”

Il resulte de tout ceci, dit le "Progres”, que les souscripteurs de la derniere emission ont perdu,par suite des pertes subies par les Sucre- ries, la garantie de l’interet de leur argent, garantie d’autant plus precieuse que cet in- teret leur avait ete paye, en tout du en partie, grace a l’apport des Sucreries et qu’ils avaient droit de computer sur cet apport jusqu a l’annee 1912. Quant aux obligataires, pour une som- me de Lst. 40,000, ils ont, perdu, pour la meme raison, la garantie du principal et des interts. La Socidtd Egyptienne d'irrigation, bien que n’ayant pas essuye de pertes materiehes du fait de la déconfitures des Sacreries, n’est done pas bien fondee a avancer qu’elle n’a subi, de ce fait, aucun contre-coup. N’est ce pas un contre coup, et des plus graves, que d’avoir perdu le garant, sous la tutelle duquel elle etait nes, e avec l‘argent duquel elle a parfait le paiement des dettes sociales.

Nous sommes convaincus que les adminis trateurs de la Societe Egyptienne se rendant parfaitement compte de la situation voudront aviser aux mesures necessaires, pour que ces contre coups n’aient pas, pour les actionnaires et les obligataires, de plus facheuses conse quences.

div.head: Conseil des Ministres
div.p: Dans sa derniere seance, le Conseil des mi- nistres a approuve l’onverture d’un nouveau credit de L.E. 10,000 pour la construction de nouveaux locaux au campement quarantenaire d’El Tor et la proposition de designer six employes des Postes pour prendre place dans le train de Port Said qui transporte le courrier de Brindisi.
Le Conseil a ensuite approuve les decrets suivants:
1° Decret declarant d’utilite publique la ligee du chemin de fer de l’Etat entre Zifta et Zagazig.

2° Decret declarant d’utilite publique les travaux de remblais a executer dans les ter- rains du Gourn a Zifta en vue de prevenir les dangers que presente actuellement ce terrain pour l’hygiene publique, d’une superficie de 13 feddans, 12 kirats, 8 sahmes.
3° Decret declarant d’utilite publique les travaux de modification a executer a la station de Beltan situee sur la ligne ferree agricole de la province de Kalioubieh.
4° Meme decret pour les travaux de cons- truction au village de Matai (Minieh) d’une maison pour le Service des irrigations. 5° Decret establissant un cimitiere musul- man a El Azazua (Dakahlieh).

div.head: La recolte du Coton
div.p: Resume des reponses recues en Septembre 1905
La temedrature du mois de Soptembre a été suffisamment chaude et favorable aux xxx- niers.
Quelques brouillards offrant, saivant les localites, plus ou moins d'intensite sont pour- tant venus joindre leurs effets a cenix de la fin Aout, et occaisonner des degats particls.

La premiere cueillette se fait actuellement partout; elle a commence de quelques jours en retard sur l'annee derniere, mais l’on est satis- fait du resultat que l'on espere, en general, su- perieur a celui de 1904.
Josqu’a ce jour, les rendements a l’egre- nage, sont d'environ 4 % inferieurs a ceux de l’annee precedente.

Les informations de la Basse-Egypte, sans etre aussi favorables qu’a la fin du mois d’aout, sont dans l'ensemble satisfaisants, mais le resultat definitif depend encore des influences atmospheriques d'Octobre.
Dans la Haute-Egypte et le Fayunm l’on constate des degats considerables et malge l’accroissement de l’acreage, on n'est pas sur d’avoir une augmentation de recolte.

div.head: SOCIETE ANONYME DES EAUX DU CAIRE
div.p: A. Paiement de coupons.
B. Fractionnement des actions.
A partir du ler octobre prochain, la Societe payera le solde du dividende de l’Exercise 1904, savoir:
Action de capital, coupon N. 32, L.E 0.427m/m

„ jouissance, „ „ 22, „ 0.434 „ Part de fondateur, „ „ 32, „ 0.616 „ et procedera en meme temps a l’echange des nouvelles actions contre celles actuelles dont le fractionnement a été decide par l’Assemblee generale extraordinaire du 9 Mars 1905. . Les interesses auront donc a presenter leurs litres en meme temps que les bordereaux numériques des coupons.
Les coupons mentionnes ci dessus ne devront pas etre detaches. Ils resteront attaches aux titres presentes.

Le montant des bordereaux sera paye de suite. Quant aux titres nouveaux, en raison du travail que cette operation d’echange exi gera, ils serent delivres ulterieurement; les ac- tious a echanger seront deposes contre rece- pisses.
La remise des titres nouveaux aura lieu, aussitot que possible, sur presentation de ces recepisses.
L’echange des actions sera fait sans confor- mite de numero.
Le paiement des coupons, ainsi que l’e change des titres, sera effectue au siege de la Societe au Caire et aux guichets du Credit Lyonnais a Alexandrie.
Il eat rappele que le fractionnement des ti- tres decide par l'Assemblee genderale precitee, se fera comme suit:

a) L’action actuelle de capital sera echangee contre quatre actions de "jouissance” et une action de “capital” — cette derniere d’une valeur nominale de 125 Fr. donnant droit a un interet fixe de 4% et remboursable par voie de tirages annuels.

b) L’action actuelle de “jouissance" sera echangee contre quatre actions de “jouissance.” c) Le fractionement des Parts de fonda teur” en dixiemes, a ete egalement decide, mais il est facultif et le porteur qui en fera la demande aura a payer les frais de con- fection des nonveaux titres.
Le Directeur p.i. L. Galvin. Le Cairo, le 14 Septembre 1905. 26428-6-5

div.head: Societe de la Daira Sanieh.
NOTICE.
div.p: Notice is hereby given that at a Board Meeting of the above mentioned Company held in Cairo on 5th instant, it was decided that an interim dividend of £10 per share on the Ordinary Shares of £5 each and £78 per share on the Deterred Shares of £1 each should be paid on and after the 16th October 1905 at the Offices of the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo, Alexandria, and London (Pay- ment will be made in London less income Tax.) Holders of Share Warrants to Bearer of the Daira Sanieh Co. Ltd. must deposit with the National Bank of Egypt, said Warrants (cou- pons N°. 7 and onwards must be attached) in exchange for which they will receive Share Warrants to Bearer of the Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh—Share for Share-simul- taneously with the above mentioned interim dividend.
The exchange og Warrants implies, ipso facto, the payment of above mentioned interim dividend.
By Order, S. DE Bilinski, 26533-2 1 Secretary.

Remarques (De midi a 1h. p.m.)

Coton.— La speculation, prenant pour pretexte, quoique a tort, le resume de la Produce Association qu’elle a voulu faire passer pour mauvais, s’est mise carrement aux achats, soit comme couvertures, soit pour aller a la hausse, et la conseqnence de cette demande soudaine a ete la hausse des prix que l’on remarque entre le cours d’ouverture et celqi de clotre.
Le marche a ete tres actif et les affaires traitees se sont élevées a un chiffre tres im- portant.
Par contre, le disponible a ete calme, mais sana changement dans les prix. Graines de coton.—Marche inactif, mais prix fermes.
Feves.—Marche nul. Bourse Khediviale, le 7 octobre 1905.
